homepage.jumbo: The wild world is closer than you think: join us in discovering it!

mission.paragraph:
*Insubria Wildlife APS* is the young, dynamic and international voice of scientific dissemination about *wildlife* and the *Insubrian environments*. We want to bring the value of biodiversity into the spotlight, making it accessible and interesting for everyone, inspiring curiosity and awareness.
*The protection* of natural resources can enrich everyone's life and our territory is rich in them: it's up to us to protect it.

Through social media, events and collaborations with experts, we want to create a meeting place for enthusiasts, professionals and curious people, stimulating debates and exchanges between people with different backgrounds.
mission.description: you will discover different realities and be part of a community with whom to share the same goals.
mission.eventsLink: Want to keep up with our events?

help.title: Have you found an animal but you don't know what to do?
help.buttonAriaLabel: Button to the Wildlife rescue page

vision.paragraph: We envision an Insubria where wildlife and environments coexist in synergy with the local community, where everyone can play an active role. Our vision extends beyond the horizon, aiming to:

visions.alt: Image of some kids sitting around a table and playing with some handmade animal-themed cards
visions.description: Become a beacon in social promotion, creating a vibrant community of citizens who are aware and active in the conservation of environment and wildlife.

visions.alt: Image of two people repairing a canopy
visions.description: Create a place where volunteering can take many forms, and is always a stimulating and educational activity.

visions.alt: Image of a rabbit drinking from a syringe
visions.description: Create a state-of-the-art wildlife recovery center, where wildlife in difficulty receives care and is released back into their territory of origin, maintaining their wild characteristics.

visions.alt: Image of a prehistoric mammal skeleton mounted on a display stand
visions.description: Establish collaborations with universities, research institutions and organizations to actively contribute to knowledge and scientific research.

visions.alt: Image of some professionists on a river shore looking for animals using their binoculars
visions.description: Create a network among sector professionals to make our actions in the territory transparent and uniform, to enrich ourselves with insights from other Italian areas and from across borders.

history.firstParagraph:
The ancient Romans called *Insubri* the people who inhabited some northern areas of modern-day Italy.

*Archaeological findings dating back to 9000 years ago* have been discovered, telling us about people who lived in the territories between the *Serio and Sesia rivers, north of the Toce valleys, the Swiss cantons of Ticino and Graubünden, and south of the Po river*. Subsequently, three different cultures emerged:

isolino.name: of Isolino,
isolino.explanation: called this way because the inhabitants built a stilt village on Isolino Virginia in Lake of Varese, considered to be the oldest lake in the Alpine arc

history.secondParagraph:
The Insubric region, although not well defined, *follows the footsteps of the ancient Insubri*, and today's populations share some cultural and dialectal aspects.

*It remains characterized by extremely rich biodiversity, among the highest in the Lombardy region*, but also very high urbanization, thanks to the numerous resources present there.

Due to the complex geological history and geomorphological variety of the territory, we can distinguish, especially in the Varese and Como Prealps, *different forest habitats and many others linked to wetlands*. The continental biogeographic region also contains several peculiar habitats rich in plant and animal species.

why.thirdParagraph:
We have chosen to focus on this territory precisely because we recognize its natural value and also the critical issues of the meeting between the two worlds, namely the natural and the urbanized and industrialized one.

We deeply believe that proper enhancement and management of the territory can give life to a profitable coexistence between humans and nature, and consequently lead the community to appreciate the beauty of their territory.

logo.title: Our Logo
logo.explanation: Our logo is a *Firecrest* - _Regulus ignicapilla_ - and here's why we chose it:
logo.fourthParagraph: Like this small bird that tirelessly explores its environment, we are committed to discovering and sharing the hidden treasures of our territory.

characteristics.description: At 9-10 cm, the Firecrest is one of Europe's smallest birds. Despite its size, it manages to undertake migrations, adapting to different habitats. Just like us, who have moved and adapted to different professional contexts, always guided by our passion for nature.
The Firecrest, a fast and agile bird, often goes unnoticed by non-experts: similarly, the naturalistic riches of Insubria are present but sometimes hidden and little known.

While adapting to various environments, from sea level up to 2400 meters in altitude, the Firecrest is sensitive to environmental changes. This characteristic reflects our mission to promote ecological awareness in a heavily anthropized territory.

Firecrest often join birds of other species forming mixed flocks, showing a social and curious nature. Similarly, we at Insubria Wildlife aim to create connections, stimulate curiosity and promote knowledge exchange between people with different backgrounds.
Finally, its bright yellow-orange crest represents that spark of creativity and flair that distinguishes our enthusiasm, our ideas and the numerous projects we have in mind for Insubria Wildlife.

team.title: our team
team.paragraph:
*We are a group of professionals* with diverse backgrounds: natural sciences, biology, veterinary medicine, journalism, social sciences, and communication. *We are united by our passion for nature and our territory*, having met at a wildlife care and rehabilitation center where we had the opportunity to work, do internships, and dedicate time to volunteering for many years.

 Over the years our paths have diverged, with job changes, moves to different cities and even nations, only to always find ourselves back together: birdwatching, forest walks, listening to deer calls, travels and discoveries are just some of our favorite activities.

*The desire to see our territory valued from a naturalistic perspective and to see the community more involved prompted us to take a big step: bringing our association to life*.

 We hope to share this adventure with you and to realize many small dreams together!

0.name: Ilaria
0.title: President
0.description: A naturalist since I can remember. I looked at pictures of plants, animals, minerals and stars and understood what my path was. The passion for animals, however, was born much earlier, when a wet nose woke me up in my crib, and never left me since; when I spent time in the garden with my grandmother learning names of flowers that I would later forget, because I was busy watching a lizard, a bee or chasing a passing bird. Today part of my job is trying to convey the wonder I feel at every little discovery...if I don't get lost in it!

1.name: Alessia
1.title: Vice President
1.description: I couldn't imagine my life away from the natural world: that's why I chose this path even before I was aware of it. Deeply passionate and curious, as soon as I could, I traveled: for leisure and work, in Italy and abroad, taking part in volunteer projects. Every time I returned home, I found myself enriched with broader professional and personal experience. I've always loved learning and sharing with the people around me, and in my free time I travel, sleep in tents, read and draw (mostly feathered friends!)

2.name: Elena
2.title: Secretary
2.description: Always passionate about animals and nature, I entered this world (almost 20 years ago) through an association working in environmental monitoring. Since then, I have collaborated with many associations as a science communicator, guide in protected oases and wildlife parks, and for education in schools. Volunteering gave me the opportunity to come into contact with wildlife, and I still work in this field today. I am excited about my journey and the countless opportunities it has given me, but I am even more excited thinking about the support I will be able to give to Insubria Wildlife and everything that this new adventure will be able to give me!

3.name: Giulia
3.title: Advisor
3.description: I still vividly remember when my passion for animals first appeared in my thoughts. At 7 years old, though, you're not yet fully aware of it. A raptor accidentally hit my grandparents' front door: I picked it up very carefully, went down to the garden, and when I slightly loosened my grip, it took flight in an instant. Something clicked in me that day: a feeling, a love for wildlife, that wasn't yet ready to fully bloom. It did during my university years, along with the certainty that it would never leave me again. Today I've made my passion my job. I love spending time outdoors, in the woods, in the company of my dogs or even just in silence with my camera, waiting for a kingfisher to perch on the branch in front of me.

4.name: Maura
4.title: Advisor
4.description: If the first word you say when you're little is 'dog', it means that somewhere your path is already set. Becoming a veterinarian was a dream that came true, but encountering wildlife took a large part of my heart. During my Erasmus project at a university clinic, I had a small otter as a patient, followed by raptors and bats: these experiences only strengthened my love for wildlife, culminating in an internship at a Wildlife Recovery Center, where I discovered the world of local fauna and the value of volunteering.

5.name: Roberto
5.title: Advisor
5.description: Nature has always had an attractive side for me: a deep feeling, difficult to explain in words. It's my passion, my outlet, my safe harbor. Where I learn new things and spend time with the people I love: I've also made it my job, becoming a safari guide in Africa. With Insubria Wildlife, I want to lead people to explore the wonderful local nature, often little known.

team.findOutButton: Button to open the card description

events.firstParagraph: If you're curious to see Insubria WildLife's activities scroll through the posters, you'll find the past events and those we have scheduled

0.title: news from geed deeble
0.alt: Event poster image about cheetahs: News from Geed Deeble
0.description:
In this meeting, we will present the work of the Cheetah Conservation Fund (CCF) in Somaliland on the rehabilitation of cheetah cubs rescued from illegal trade.

It is estimated that more than 300 cubs are taken from their mothers every year to be sold on the black market: there are many questions about this, such as where they go, why they are taken, and what associations and local authorities are actually doing about it. You can find out by joining this free online meeting.

Veterinary technician Alessia Uboldi will talk about her field experience, followed by CCF President Betty Von Hoenning, who will explain how the association's resources are used and show some videos; finally, we will return to our country and move to the Insubric territory with Giulia Gavioli, board member and co-founder of Insubria WildLife APS, who will present the association.

We look forward to seeing many of you there!

1.title: spring in marsh
1.alt: Event poster image for Spring in the Marsh: Spring in the Marsh
1.ticket: Booking is mandatory via email by using the link in the description
1.description:
It is not essential to reach foreign and distant destinations to observe spectacular and interesting animal and plant species: sometimes these hide from our eyes, even if they live just a few steps away from us.

Spring is the ultimate symbol of awakening, where plants and animals return to enjoy the warmth of the Sun.
The province of Varese offers very interesting landscape features, especially in the LIPU Palude Brabbia Oasis: from the abundant flowering of woodland plants to birdwatching, as this is a very important crossroads for birds.

The workshop will be conducted by 3 professionals in the field.

To participate you need to register,

speakers.name: Marco Colombo
speakers.description:
Nature enthusiast and wildlife photographer since 1999.

With a degree in Natural Sciences, he is also a scuba diving instructor and scientific consultant for the TV show GEO on Rai3: his photos and scientific articles have been published in magazines such as National Geographic and in identification and wildlife photography books.

He has participated in numerous international competitions, winning prestigious awards, and is the author of exhibitions, projections, and conferences, as well as a teacher in wildlife photography courses.

For further details, his works can be viewed here

speakers.name: Giulia Gavioli
speakers.description:
Graduate in Animal Breeding and Welfare (2019) and in Evolution of Animal and Human Behavior (2022).

She conducted an internship on the European hedgehog and wrote a thesis on the Marsican bear in the Maiella National Park, working on the LIFE ARCPROM project: she monitored wolves in Portugal through the ERASMUS program.

She is a board member of Insubria WildLife and works in scientific communication.

speakers.name: Alessia Uboldi
speakers.description:
Graduate in Animal Breeding and Welfare, she has a Master's in Wildlife Management and Conservation and is a wildlife technician and veterinarian with over 7 years of experience in wildlife rehabilitation.

She has worked at the C.R.A.S. of Vanzago and in Somaliland for the Cheetah Conservation Fund. Currently a researcher at the Swiss Ornithological Institute, she is involved in field monitoring, data analysis and laboratory work on several migratory bird species, with experiences in Europe and Africa.

She is the vice president of Insubria WildLife.

2.title: equilibrinatura
2.alt: Event poster image about the event equilibrinatura
2.ticket: Booking is mandatory via email by using the link in the description
2.description:
The event will focus on the relationship between humans and nature, with particular attention to the coexistence between human activities and wildlife, and will develop in two moments:

Educational workshop for children and families
During the morning, children aged 5 to 10, together with their families, will participate in an educational activity on pollinating insects: through a practical and participatory approach, their fundamental role in the ecosystem will be illustrated and components of a "Community Bug Hotel" will be built, which will then be installed in a public area of the Municipality. The goal is to raise awareness among the youngest about the importance of biodiversity and promote environmental protection practices related to sustainable agriculture.

Screening of the film "Dangerously Close", with public discussion for adults and young people
In the late afternoon, in collaboration with the association "I Benandanti APS", a space for discussion will open on the relationship between the community and wildlife and on strategies for coexistence with humans, with a focus on species present in the territory such as wild boars and deer. The meeting will draw inspiration from the dynamics narrated in the documentary "Dangerously Close" by Andreas Pichler, which explores the different perspectives on the topic of large carnivores and coexistence with wildlife. Afterwards, an aperitif will offer the opportunity for an informal exchange of opinions among participants.

To participate you need to register

3.title: Paws in the city and like in the savannah
3.alt: Event poster image about the event Paws in the city and like in the savannah
3.location: Via Jean Henry Dunant 3, 21100 Varese (VA)
3.description:
Have you ever thought about how a like or a comment can actually contribute to the illegal trade of wild animals?
Do you know how to recognize fake news?
How can you identify a sensationalist headline that has no scientific basis?

These and other questions about the conscious use of social media will be answered by the speakers participating in this meeting:

  • Alessia Uboldi
  • Giulia Gavioli

members of the Insubria WildLife association will present 'From the savannah to the feed: when a like threatens biodiversity'.

while

  • Adriano Martinoli

professor at the University of Insubria will present 'Wildlife in the city: the new citizens and the anecdotes of this coexistence'.

A debate session will follow at the end of the presentations.

Admission is free and open to everyone without reservation.

speakers.name: Adriano Martinoli
speakers.description: Zoology teacher at Università degli Studi dell'Insubria.

4.title: Fireflies into the woods
4.alt: Event poster image about the event Fireflies into the woods
4.ticket: Booking is mandatory via email by using the link in the description
4.description:
May arrives, bringing with it the opportunity to spend much more time outdoors, with warmer and brighter days. And for us at Insubria WildLife, every occasion is the perfect one to take you to discover the hidden gems of our beloved territory!

We invite you to an evening at the Roccolo di Vegonno where, immersed in the tranquility of the forest with only the sounds of the night as your soundtrack, we will walk among the calls of tawny owls and little owls in search of the increasingly rare fireflies.
An evening with a magical atmosphere that will end with the chance to chat around a bonfire, with music and marshmallows!

Our guide will be Roberto, a member of Insubria WildLife, and the participation fee is €10.

To participate you need to register,

speakers.name: Roberto Paone
speakers.description:
Safari Guide certified since 2022 and Tour Leader for Sto Gran Tour since the end of 2022.

He has accompanied numerous organized travel groups around the world, for example to Iceland, Jordan, South Africa, and Namibia: he aims to see the entire world, and he's getting ready to do so.

He is a great lover and connoisseur of our local wildlife, as well as a tireless walker.

5.title: BioBlitz Poglianasca
5.alt: Event poster image about the event BioBlitz Poglianasca
5.ticket: Reservation on iNaturalist app, instructions in the event description
5.description:
We look forward to seeing you on Sunday for a Biodiversity Treasure Hunt!

Do you know what a BioBlitz is? Together we will discover how much natural richness can be found in the countryside around Cascina Poglianasca through an interactive game.

All you need to do is download the iNaturalist app, search for our project 'Bio Blitz Poglianasca' in the 'Projects' section, sign up, and show up at the Cascina at 3:30 PM.
You can find the app on the main digital stores: for iPhone on the App Store and for Android on Google Play.

For more information, you can contact us using the contact form.

6.title: Natural CurioCity
6.alt: Event poster image about the event Natural CurioCity
6.location: Viale Giovan Battista Vico, 21100 Varese (VA)
6.ticket: Booking is mandatory via email by using the link in the description
6.description:
Has it ever happened to you to take a walk in a park or forest and wonder how much biodiversity exists in our provinces?
Very often we don't think about it, but our territories are incredibly rich in different animal and plant species, all interacting in a perfect balance.

In this event, we will explore the biodiversity treasure hidden within the province of Varese, thanks to two professionals from the University of Insubria who specialize in the study of the red squirrel, a little friend that lives in our cities:

  • Claudia Tranquillo

Zoologist and PhD candidate at the University, focusing on the conservation and management of wildlife in natural and urban environments.
Her talk will be 'Nature in the city: challenges and opportunities of urban wildlife - Getting to know the red squirrels that live in our parks'.

  • Alessandro Sclip

Wildlife technician at the University, specialized in wildlife management with a particular focus on small mammals.
His talk will be 'Alien presences among the buildings - Learning to recognize invasive squirrels to protect biodiversity'.

Following the talks, there will be two activities in the beautiful setting of Villa Toeplitz: a BioBlitz, meaning a flora-and-fauna-themed treasure hunt, and a Clean-Up of the villa grounds.

To participate you need to register,

7.title: BioTalks
7.alt: Event poster image about the event BioTalks
7.description:
BioTalks are four educational events, hosted by the Groane Park and taking place between September and October.

Together with young researchers, technicians, and science communication experts, we will talk about biodiversity, habitats, coexistence, restoration actions, and much more.

An open and stimulating dialogue, with opportunities for the audience to join the discussion as well.

Admission is free (until all seats are taken), but to ensure your participation, registration is required using the contact form.

8.title: December events
8.alt: Event poster image about the December events
8.location:
Thursday 11th: Via Provinciale, 47-49, 22038 Tavernerio (CO)
Saturday 13th: Via Como, 21, 21100 Varese (VA)
Sunday 14th: Piazza Giovanni Albinola, 21059 Viggiù (VA)
8.calendar: Thursday 11th h 9:00 PM, Saturday 13th h 3:00 PM and Sunday 14th
8.ticket:
Thursday 11th: No booking, free entry
Saturday 13th: booking is mandatory via email by using the link in the description
8.description:
Here are all the December events for Insubria WildLife!

  • Thursday, December 11th

    Alessia Uboldi will be a guest of Consulta Giovani Tavernerio for an Aperitivo with Nature focused on birdlife.
    Admission is free.

  • Saturday, December 13th

    Laura Corigliano and Alessia Uboldi will guide you in exploring the world of watercolors, with the creation of Christmas cards themed around the holidays and wildlife.
    Admission is free with a voluntary donation, but registration is required to participate.

  • Sunday, December 14th

    See you at a Christmas market where you'll find lots of gadgets and handmade items created by us, all nature-themed!

9.title: Wild Xmas Cards
9.alt: Event poster image about the event Wild Xmas Cards
9.ticket: Booking is mandatory via email by using the link in the description
9.description:
The Christmas-themed watercolor workshop featuring wildlife!

Would you like to create your own nature-themed Christmas card?
Thanks to Laura Corigliano and Alessia Uboldi, we will learn the basics of this wonderful technique, creating Christmas cards together… wild ones!

Admission is free with a voluntary donation but to participate you need to register,.

sosAnimals.firstParagraph: Have you found an animal but you don't know what to do?
sosAnimals.fourthParagraph: no human cure can be better than the parents' care!
sosAnimals.fifthParagraph: *Before intervening, make sure it's really necessary.*

aria-labels.cras: Go to the CRAS list website

sosCards.alt: Image of a box with a cloth and a bottle filled with warm water inside
sosCards.title: Transport
sosCards.description:
Proper transport is essential to avoid additional stress or injuries: choose a box of the right size to limit excessive movement, while allowing the animal to stay in an upright position.

Use absorbent paper or soft cloth on the bottom, making sure there are no threads that could tangle around legs and wings.

In case of shock, hairless/featherless animal, or obvious hypothermia, add a heat source, such as a hot water bottle: however, it's crucial that the animal is never in direct contact with it, so wrap cloth or absorbent paper around the heat source and, in case of a bottle, use tape to secure it to the box. In any case, always give the animal the possibility to move away from it if needed.

Finally, close the box with a perforated lid to ensure ventilation.

sosCards.alt: Image of a hedgehog drinking milk
sosCards.title: Food and water
sosCards.description:
Wildlife, especially when in difficulty, is particularly sensitive to unsuitable food, which can cause various problems, even leading to death: for this reason, you should always avoid feeding animals.


Here's a brief list of foods to absolutely avoid:

  • Cow's milk and dairy products in general
  • Bread
  • Cookies
  • Sweets
  • Processed foods

Regarding hydration, water should only be given to alert and responsive animals, taking care to choose containers suitable for the animal's size: if too bulky, they could be accidentally hit by some of the animal's movements and spill their contents, ending up wetting the box and the animal itself.
For small sizes, such as birds or very small cubs, a jar lid is usually sufficient.


If you cannot directly bring the specimen to a c.r.a.s., contact them and ask for specific advice

sosCards.alt: Image of a little bird over a human hand
sosCards.title: Who to call
sosCards.description:
Scattered across the territory there are Wildlife Recovery Centers or C.R.A.S.


What are they?


These are centers set up for the care and recovery of wildlife, however unfortunately not all of them have the ability to rescue a specimen in difficulty: in this case the responsibility falls to the Provincial Police.


At the following link you can find the complete list of C.R.A.S., divided by region https://elencocras.it/

sosCards.alt: Image of two little naked mammals over a human hand
sosCards.title: Naked mammals
sosCards.description:
If naked with closed eyes or out of the nest, they always need intervention.


Returning them to the nest is possible and advisable if they are not injured and show certain vitality (if they move, are warm, and react when stimulated) and if the nest is accessible and intact.


Use gloves or cloth to avoid leaving your scent, otherwise the parent might abandon them!

Once repositioned in the den, you must move away (never stay in sight), monitor the activity of cubs and parents for the next 4-6 hours and, meanwhile, contact the c.r.a.s.

sosCards.alt: Image of a little fawn laying on the grass
sosCards.title: Young mammals with fur
sosCards.description:
Young animals are not always abandoned.


Cubs with developed fur and wide open eyes begin exploring the territory, so it's not uncommon to find young hares, rabbits, or squirrels alone: it's part of their life cycle.


This is completely normal and essential for their growth, so they should not be rescued.


Roe and red deer fawns are emblematic: they are born odorless and when mothers leave to feed, they hide them in vegetation for extended periods. Being odorless protects them from predators but, if touched, they will acquire a scent foreign to the mother and will be abandoned!


If the discovery area presents dangers, it's good practice to contact the c.r.a.s.. for advice.

sosCards.alt: Image of a bird over a sprit
sosCards.title: Birds out of the nest
sosCards.description:
Like human beings learn to walk with time and practice, many young birds spend time learning the basics of flight, and they do this on the ground. This is normal.

However, we need to make distinctions to act in the best way. We might encounter:

  • Birds born without feathers

    This category includes birds like blackbirds, sparrows, and crows: if found outside the nest without complete plumage, they need our intervention. If possible, they should be put back in the nest and monitored from afar (even for 4-5 hours), to ensure parents approach.

    • If completely covered with feathers and plumes

      They are in the exploration and learning phase: they are practicing flying, so they should not be removed from the territory and taken away from parental care, as parents still monitor and feed them occasionally.

  • Birds born covered in down

    This category includes birds like owls, kestrels, tawny owls, wood pigeons: if found at this stage, they should be returned to their nest or placed in an artificial one, protected (like a box) but accessible to parents, who will continue caring for the chick (always contact the c.r.a.s. for more specific advice).

    • If completely covered in plumage

      As mentioned above, they are learning to fly, so should not be removed from the ground.

This is a fundamental phase for the animal's growth and, if deprived of it, they will have less chance of survival in the future.

sosCards.title: Common Swifts, Swallows and House Martins
sosCards.description:
Usually, swallow and house martin nests are clearly visible, and if we find a chick in good condition, it should be returned to the nest.


These animals have extremely short legs (especially swifts) because they are highly specialized for life in flight: for this reason they might struggle to take off from the ground, and this applies not only to chicks but also to adult specimens!


A swift on the ground, therefore, always needs to be rescued.


You can contact the c.r.a.s. and request assistance by sending photos, to evaluate whether to attempt a release back into nature or if recovery care is needed.

sosCards.title: Bats
sosCards.description:
They should never be touched with bare hands! Use gardening gloves or a cloth.


We need to make distinctions to act appropriately. If:

  • The specimen is a baby or young (recognizable by absent or short fur)

    • If in good condition, reuniting with the colony might be possible: for more information contact the Bat Helpdesk at +39 347 3941266

    • If injured, unresponsive or visibly thin (showing hollowness at shoulder blades and pelvis), needs immediate rescue by taking it to one of the c.r.a.s.

  • The specimen is adult (covered in fur and body length varying from 3 to 10 cm depending on species)

    If found on the ground, exposed to sun, clinging to a wall at low height, or brought by a cat, needs immediate rescue, also in this case by taking it to one of the c.r.a.s.


For more information visit the Bat Helpdesk

contactUs.firstTitle: Do you need to contact us? Compile the form below, we will reply as soon as possible
contactUs.name: Name

supportUs.firstTitle: Do you want to help us make our dream come true?

list.listTitle: Support our mission with a donation

supportUs.paragraph: Every contribution, big or small, helps us protect wildlife and preserve our territory for future generations.
supportUs.secondTitle: Do you share our vision and values?
supportUs.secondParagraph: Are you full of ideas, passion and keen to get involved? Join us
supportUs.thirdParagraph: and become part of *Insubria WildLife*: we are always looking for *free, innovative and enthusiastic voices* to build together a better future for nature.

cookieBanner.title: The best cookies are those that stay between us
cookieBanner.description:
Just like the flora and fauna that remain in their habitat, the cookie we use stays between us: we neither collect nor transfer any of your data to third parties. We only use a cookie that is strictly necessary for the functioning of the site, specifically to allow navigation in the language you selected.

By continuing to browse, you accept their use.
